review.title: “Ok if you aren't ambitious”

review.cons: Cons – Power is centered in very few people, who are generally not open to new ideas.
review.advice-to-management: No, I would not recommend this company to a friend

review.title: “Only perks are good, the overall culture needs an improvement.”

review.title: “Don't stuck in that company for more than 3 years”

review.cons: Cons – No appreciation from seniors if you have done some extremely well..less man power...that's why some times you have to work more than 12 hrs..poor management skills from seniors..on work loads..most of the seniors never help to trainee product engineer and lead product engineer and in this work load if some issue occurs..then they blame in such a way that your really very stupid that you work here and you have proved your stupidity here..that u can't do such simple work they will never count your man power and work load..management will curse you
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Please use some more man power..and more technical stuff..your work is increasing but not the man power..

review.title: “It used to be a great place to work”
review.pros: Pros – - Great people, a lot of smart and very talented employees- Interesting and challenging projects, sense of as part of a big thing- Great benefits plan- Good work-life balance
review.cons: Cons – - A 'fire,aim,ready' culture that takes its direction from sales.- Too much chaos and lack of communication from VP level down to middle management and employee base, causing lack of stability to build long term plans.- Brand new senior leadership not trusting or understanding the roles of front line managers and support personnel.- Reinventing the messaging wheel every year. "Our target market is now this, no wait this is our target market this year. Our new market messaging is going to be this, wait it’s a new year, let’s coin a new phrase that our customers do not use or understand and re-position the company, again!".- Improper focus on the bottom line versus product innovation, quality and serving the customer.- Employees no longer the #1 asset of the company, which does not align with parent company of SAS Institute. Revenue - regardless of how we get there, who we alienate (partners/customers) and how we treat employees is the main focus of the company.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Listen and trust your middle management and support personnel who, at one point, took pride in working for the company. Too many pinheads with so called “know-how” are placed in senior management positions - those with poor leadership, interpersonal and business skills.
